pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 185, 905, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 207, 905, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2018  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 228, 905, 242]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 342, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 458, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 548, 358, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 623, 91]]<|/det|>
A length of cotton is measured between two points on a ruler.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 97, 876, 185]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 196, 784, 216]]<|/det|>
When the length of cotton is wound closely around a pen, it goes round six times.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 222, 702, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 294, 463, 312]]<|/det|>
What is the distance once round the pen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 323, 133, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 323, 208, 342]]<|/det|>
2.2cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 323, 298, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 323, 376, 342]]<|/det|>
2.6cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 323, 470, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 323, 551, 342]]<|/det|>
13.2cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 323, 636, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 323, 720, 342]]<|/det|>
15.6cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 368, 92, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 749, 387]]<|/det|>
When does an object falling vertically through the air reach terminal velocity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 396, 133, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 396, 598, 415]]<|/det|>
when the acceleration of the object becomes negative

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 425, 133, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 425, 549, 443]]<|/det|>
when the acceleration of the object is equal to \(g\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 131, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 452, 603, 470]]<|/det|>
when the air resistance equals the weight of the object

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 477, 133, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 477, 667, 496]]<|/det|>
when the air resistance is greater than the weight of the object

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 712, 89]]<|/det|>
A car is moving along a straight, level road, with a constant acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 468, 119]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows the motion of the car?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 128, 803, 508]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 880, 90]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows a beam balance. A beaker with a wire loop balances the standard masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 922, 136]]<|/det|>
The beaker is then removed and hung from a spring. The spring extends by \(5.0 \text{cm}\), as in diagram 2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 144, 907, 356]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated with the same apparatus on the Moon, where the acceleration of free fall is less than on Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 581, 432]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes what happens on the Moon?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 441, 134, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 441, 688, 460]]<|/det|>
The beam balance is balanced and the spring extends by 5.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 468, 134, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 467, 767, 486]]<|/det|>
The beam balance is balanced and the spring extends by less than 5.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 131, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 737, 512]]<|/det|>
The right-hand balance pan is higher and the spring extends by 5.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 521, 131, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 816, 539]]<|/det|>
The right-hand balance pan is higher and the spring extends by less than 5.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 564, 134, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 564, 621, 583]]<|/det|>
An object always has mass but does not always have weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 594, 675, 612]]<|/det|>
What must be present and acting on the mass for it to have weight?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 623, 134, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 623, 311, 641]]<|/det|>
a gravitational field

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 134, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 650, 275, 667]]<|/det|>
a set of scales

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 134, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 675, 285, 693]]<|/det|>
displaced water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 134, 719]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 701, 384, 719]]<|/det|>
friction due to air resistance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 744, 97, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 744, 828, 763]]<|/det|>
A force acting on a moving ball causes its motion to change. This force stays constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 774, 725, 793]]<|/det|>
What makes the force produce a greater change in the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 803, 134, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 803, 453, 821]]<|/det|>
decreasing the total mass of the ball

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 830, 134, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 830, 463, 848]]<|/det|>
increasing the temperature of the ball

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 857, 131, 875]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 857, 579, 875]]<|/det|>
using a ball with a hollow centre but the same mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 883, 134, 902]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 883, 850, 900]]<|/det|>
using a different material for the ball so that it has a lower density but the same mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
A balloon and a mass are attached to a rod that is pivoted at P.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 98, 712, 261]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 273, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
The balloon is filled with helium, a gas less dense than air, so that it applies an upward force on the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 319, 413, 337]]<|/det|>
The rod is horizontal and stationary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 349, 520, 367]]<|/det|>
Which action causes the rod to rotate clockwise?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 133, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 377, 562, 395]]<|/det|>
Move both the balloon and mass \(10\mathrm{cm}\) to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 133, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 403, 574, 421]]<|/det|>
Move both the balloon and mass \(10\mathrm{cm}\) to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 429, 133, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 429, 579, 448]]<|/det|>
Move both the balloon and mass to the \(25 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 133, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 456, 719, 473]]<|/det|>
Move the balloon to the \(20 \text{cm}\) mark and the mass to the \(30 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 96, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 920, 533]]<|/det|>
A car is moving in a straight line on a level road. Its engine provides a forward force on the car. A second force of equal size acts on the car due to resistive forces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 475, 562]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes what happens?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 133, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 574, 373, 592]]<|/det|>
The car changes direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 133, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 600, 450, 618]]<|/det|>
The car moves at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 627, 133, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 627, 324, 644]]<|/det|>
The car slows down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 133, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 653, 311, 670]]<|/det|>
The car speeds up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 695, 96, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 695, 554, 714]]<|/det|>
Which expression gives the momentum of an object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 725, 133, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 725, 320, 744]]<|/det|>
mass \(\times\) acceleration

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 752, 133, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 752, 432, 771]]<|/det|>
mass \(\times\) gravitational field strength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 133, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 780, 282, 797]]<|/det|>
mass \(\times\) velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 808, 133, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 808, 339, 826]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} \times \text{mass} \times (\text{velocity})^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 757, 89]]<|/det|>
As energy is transferred into different forms, it eventually becomes dissipated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 304, 119]]<|/det|>
What does this mean?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 369, 147]]<|/det|>
All the energy disappears.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 133, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 665, 174]]<|/det|>
The energy finally changes into every possible form of energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 702, 201]]<|/det|>
The energy spreads out among the objects and their surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 500, 225]]<|/det|>
The total amount of energy becomes less.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
A ball of mass \(1.2\mathrm{kg}\) is dropped from a height of \(30\mathrm{m}.\) As it falls, \(25\%\) of its initial gravitational potential energy is transferred to thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 663, 316]]<|/det|>
What is the kinetic energy of the ball just before it hits the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 133, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 327, 175, 345]]<|/det|>
27 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 327, 303, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 327, 344, 345]]<|/det|>
90 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 327, 485, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 327, 525, 345]]<|/det|>
270 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 327, 640, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[645, 327, 700, 345]]<|/det|>
360 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 371, 107, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
A girl hangs by her hands from a bar in the gymnasium. She pulls herself up until her chin is level with the bar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 354, 434]]<|/det|>
The mass of the girl is \(48\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 446, 524, 464]]<|/det|>
She pulls herself up through a distance of \(0.25 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 299, 494]]<|/det|>
She does this in 2.0 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 554, 524]]<|/det|>
What is the useful power she uses to pull herself up?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 133, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 535, 201, 553]]<|/det|>
6.0 W

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 535, 313, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 535, 364, 553]]<|/det|>
24 W

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 535, 480, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 535, 532, 553]]<|/det|>
60 W

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 535, 636, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 535, 710, 553]]<|/det|>
240 W

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 580, 107, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
Four identical beakers are filled with equal volumes of liquids P or Q, as shown. Liquid P is more dense than liquid Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 448, 642]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 650, 855, 752]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 778, 106, 796]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 778, 742, 796]]<|/det|>
An oil tank has a base of area \(2.5 \text{m}^2\) and is filled with oil to a depth of \(1.2 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 808, 405, 826]]<|/det|>
The density of the oil is \(800 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 838, 641, 856]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 866, 133, 884]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 866, 201, 884]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 866, 303, 884]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 866, 381, 884]]<|/det|>
2400 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 866, 470, 884]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 866, 548, 884]]<|/det|>
9600 N

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 866, 728, 884]]<|/det|>
24 000 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 890, 89]]<|/det|> When molecules of a gas rebound from a wall of a container, the wall experiences a pressure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 410, 119]]<|/det|> What is the cause of this pressure? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 470, 147]]<|/det|> the change in energy of the molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 156, 505, 175]]<|/det|> the change in momentum of the molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 460, 201]]<|/det|> the change in power of the molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 209, 460, 227]]<|/det|> the change in speed of the molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 255, 106, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 756, 272]]<|/det|> A student wishes to calibrate a mercury-in-glass thermometer with a \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\) scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 285, 803, 303]]<|/det|> Which values should she use for the lower fixed point and for the upper fixed point? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 656, 443]]<|/det|>
lower fixed pointupper fixed point
Amelting point of iceboiling point of mercury
Bmelting point of iceboiling point of water
Cmelting point of mercuryboiling point of mercury
Dmelting point of mercuryboiling point of water
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 470, 106, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 712, 488]]<|/det|> Which statements about boiling and about evaporation are both correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 498, 767, 631]]<|/det|>
boilingevaporation
Atakes place only at the surfacetakes place only at the surface
Btakes place only at the surfacetakes place throughout the liquid
Ctakes place throughout the liquidtakes place only at the surface
Dtakes place throughout the liquidtakes place throughout the liquid
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 657, 106, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 920, 691]]<|/det|> On a cold day, a metal front-door knob X and a similar plastic knob Y are at the same temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 484, 720]]<|/det|> Why does X feel cooler to the touch than Y? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 731, 134, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 731, 490, 749]]<|/det|> X convects thermal energy better than Y. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 134, 776]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 758, 470, 776]]<|/det|> X is a better thermal conductor than Y. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 134, 803]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 785, 393, 803]]<|/det|> X is a better insulator than Y. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 810, 134, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 810, 537, 828]]<|/det|> X is a better radiator of thermal energy than Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 336, 104, 354]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 487, 355]]<|/det|> A steel magnet is placed inside a coil of wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 542, 384]]<|/det|> Which method is used to demagnetise the magnet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 395, 134, 413]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 395, 480, 413]]<|/det|> connect the coil to an a.c. power supply <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 421, 131, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 421, 843, 440]]<|/det|> connect the coil to an a.c. power supply and slowly remove the magnet from the coil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 133, 467]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 448, 470, 467]]<|/det|> connect the coil to a d.c. power supply <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 473, 131, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 473, 833, 492]]<|/det|> connect the coil to a d.c. power supply and slowly remove the magnet from the coil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 517, 104, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 517, 658, 536]]<|/det|> The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a rechargeable battery is 6.0V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 304, 565]]<|/det|> What does this mean? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 133, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 650, 594]]<|/det|> 6.0 J is the maximum energy the battery can provide in 1.0 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 133, 621]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 602, 784, 621]]<|/det|> 6.0 J is the total energy the battery can provide before it has to be recharged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 647]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 628, 915, 647]]<|/det|> 6.0 J of energy is provided by the battery to drive a charge of 1.0 C around a complete circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 133, 673]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 912, 673]]<|/det|> 6.0 J of energy is provided by the battery to drive a current of 1.0 A around a complete circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 698, 106, 717]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 855, 717]]<|/det|> A student measures the potential difference across a device and the current in the device. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 554, 747]]<|/det|> Which calculation gives the resistance of the device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 133, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 757, 401, 775]]<|/det|> current + potential difference <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 133, 803]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 401, 803]]<|/det|> current \(\div\) potential difference <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 812, 133, 831]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 812, 401, 831]]<|/det|> potential difference \(\div\) current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 839, 133, 858]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 839, 401, 858]]<|/det|> potential difference \(\times\) current

<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 616, 89]]<|/det|>
Which statement about electromagnetic induction is correct?

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 100, 922, 134]]<|/det|>
A strong magnet that is held stationary near a stationary conductor causes a greater effect than a weak magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 141, 133, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 141, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
The effect occurs when a magnet and a conductor are both moved with the same speed and in the same direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 133, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 769, 201]]<|/det|>
The effect occurs when a magnet is moved away from a nearby conductor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 207, 725, 225]]<|/det|>
The effect only occurs when a magnet is moved towards a conductor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 848, 551]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 467, 581]]<|/det|>
What is the explanation for this reduction?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 592, 133, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 592, 615, 610]]<|/det|>
The current decreases, reducing thermal energy losses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 133, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 618, 586, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 133, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 641, 662]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 133, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 670, 472, 688]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the cable decreases.
